STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 16, 2023
Michelle Seigo
MONTCALM COUNTY DHHS
PO BOX 278,
STANTON, MI, 48888-0278
RE: License#: CP590201310
Dear Ms. Seigo:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on March 16, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP590201310
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Michelle Seigo
Name of Agency: MONTCALM COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: PO BOX 278
STANTON, MI 48888-0278
Agency Telephone #: 9898318400
Original Issuance Date: 09/01/1989
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the following
information before the placement or replacement of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child's date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the care of
the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to provide
a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do not reside in the
foster home.
Three of six open foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-h of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlined within the rule.
R 400. 12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting time
that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child and the
foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once every month.
Two of six open foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the worker
and child in the foster placement as required.

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/29/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/29/2022
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14 days of
the end of the report period.
One of six foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case service
plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/29/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/29/2022
3/29/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 4/14/2021
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including those
of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor, foster parent,
caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Five of six foster care files reviewed (12 of 22 service plans) did not contain all of the
required signatures on the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/29/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/29/2022
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in the
following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include reunification,
placement in a residential setting, step-down from a residential or
hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.

Two of six foster care files reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/29/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/29/2022
3/29/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 4/14/2021
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Four of six foster care files reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105
was not uploaded within seven business days.
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must be
provided within two weeks of the child's placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult re-
entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must be documented
in the electronic case management record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child is newly
referred to and accepted for treatment and/or services prior to or at the
first scheduled appointment while the foster care case is open,
regardless of placement. Subsequent medical passports are not
required.
• • Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age 18 and older).
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young adult:
• Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
• Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Five of six open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

3/29/2022 Interim, CAP approved 4/29/2022
3/29/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 4/14/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Upload documents in correct areas of MISACWIS.
• Check the correct box when documenting purpose of FTM’s in MISACWIS.
• Do not provide preliminary findings of special investigation to foster parents
until the investigation has been concluded.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
corrective action plan was submitted in response to licensing interim inspection
report dated 3/29/2022 and was approved on 4/29/2022. During the review the
agency had sixteen violations. Five citations were noted as repeat violations in the
current inspection. During this period under review the agency has experienced
staff turnover.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported a review of the agency’s data shows success in meeting
a majority of the requirements during this review period. Chief Administrator (CA)
stated some barriers include placement issues and unplanned removals. In
addition, the assessment noted staff turnover have impacted compliance, however
the agency has done well in managing the turnover and providing training and
additional oversight by supervision to inexperienced staff. CA stated the previous
year CAP was effective. Experienced supervision team has also positively
impacted overall compliance during the review period along with additional
oversight. CA noted the agency has effectively utilized checklists, due date
calendars and a placement committee to assist staff with the best placement
matches.

Financial Overview
No financial concerns were identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged the
agency has had some challenging cases. However, they stated coworkers and
supervision were available to assist when needed. Staff reported no areas of
concern.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_________3/16/2023____________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 16, 2023
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
